awd_titl_txt: Conference: Broadening Participation of Deaf Students in Sign Language Research - 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
Sign language research has broadened our understanding of human language processing and languages in general. Since the 1960s, there have been a growing number of sign language studies, yet the presence of deaf researchers -- users of signed languages -- is greatly underrepresented in this field. This project aims to broaden the participation of deaf individuals in disciplines that conduct sign language research. This project will support eight deaf students to present and participate in the 12th International Conference on Theoretical Issues in Sign Language (TISLR12). TISLR is the most significant and well-attended international sign language research conference. Immediately after the conference the students will participate in a one-day workshop offered by the TISLR12 conference committee on applied linguistics and the translational implications of sign language research. This project will provide American Sign Language/English interpreting services so these students will have access to this knowledge and opportunities to interact with sign language researchers from all over the world.

The selected students will each have three senior mentors who will meet with them prior to the conference, during the conference, and after the conference. The students' experiences, what they learned and/or their experiences and/or their research question and plans will be presented to the group and mentors. The knowledge learned from this program will impact the selected students with both theoretical and translational issues related to sign language research. The long-term projected outcome is an increase in deaf sign language researchers. They will disseminate their experiences to deaf students at deaf schools, in university publications, Center and laboratory publications, in ASL online through social media, and at conferences concerning broadening the participation of deaf researchers in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
Deaf researchers are underrepresented in sign language research. The major goal of this project was to broaden the participation of deaf individuals in disciplines that conduct sign language research. Funding was used to bring deaf graduate students to participate and present at the 12th annual meeting of the Theoretical Issues in Sign Language Research (TISLR) in Melbourne, Australia in January 2016. TISLR is the most significant and well-attended international sign language research conference. Sign language researchers from all over the world attend this conference. Thus, participation in this conference was an important step in the professional development of these deaf, American graduate students. The funding also allowed the provision of American Sign Language (ASL) interpreting services at the conference. With the ASL interpreting services, the students had access to the breadth of knowledge represented at the conference, and the opportunity to interact with the experts attending. The long-term projected outcome is an increase of deaf sign language researchers.

All of the American deaf students whose abstracts were selected for presentations by the TISLR conference’s scientific committee were supported by this grant. These students got the opportunity to interact with the leaders of this project, talk about their research, and present their research at TISLR. In effect, they introduced themselves to a large, international community of sign language researchers and potentially increased their career opportunities in this field. The students and PI/co-PI also met after the conference to discuss how to further broaden the participation of deaf students – particularly undergraduate and even high school students – in sign language research in the future.

The students have disseminated information about their research and their participation at TISLR through social media platforms, such as Facebook. Through university publications, the Rochester Institute of Technology and one of its colleges, the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, have disseminated information about this grant and the participating students. The grant’s efforts were mentioned in the Rochester Business Journal. Gallaudet University also highlighted their students’ presentations at TISLR via their online publications. Since the conference, many students have presented their work at U.S. conferences, written and submitted manuscripts for publications based on their findings they presented at TISLR, and one student has since successfully defended her Ph.D. dissertation.

The presence of a cohort of deaf graduate students from the U.S. was an important indication that the number of deaf sign language researchers in the U.S. is growing. Researchers in the sign language field were impressed by the sophistication and high level of research presented by these American students. Such a presence is important for the further development of the field, as well as for maximizing career advancement opportunities for the students supported by this grant. The role of deaf scientists, including sign language researchers, goes well beyond the academic impact. Deaf scientists are underrepresented in STEM, and especially in sign language research. Society benefits when the full range of human diversity is included in all activities, including scholarly pursuits.
